nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
Funerary Structure FS1
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS1 (3 m x 3 m) is a highly eroded mound and the most easterly specimen at the site. It is elevated 1 m to 1.5 m above the surrounding terrain. Some sections of walls, two vertical courses of stones in height, have persisted just below the top of the structure. They lie exposed, the earth around them having eroded away.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS2
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS2 (4.5 m x 8 m) is situated 1.8 m northwest of FS1. This largest and best preserved mound is elevated 1.5 m to 2.5 m above the surrounding terrain. The double-course wall that lined the east rim of the mound is still partially intact. This wall (around 80 cm thick) contains uncut variable-length (10 cm to 70 cm long) pieces of light-colored limestone and conglomerate. It is up to 60 cm in height and composed of three layers of stones. Small bits of the same type of wall line the south rim of the structure. There is also a small wall fragment on the north side of FS2. Some stones are partly submerged here and there in the mound, and grass grows on it.
